question: Under the 4/3 Structure Rule (Core Enhancement 5A), during play a team must have at least how many players in their own half, and at least how many outfield players in the opposition half?

options.text: At least 4 in own half (goalkeeper may be included), at least 3 outfield in opposition half
At least 3 in own half, at least 4 outfield in opposition half
At least 4 outfield in own half, at least 3 in opposition half
At least 5 in own half, at least 2 in opposition half

question: A breach of the 4/3 Structure Rule does NOT occur where the player(s) who would otherwise cause the breach: (Select all that apply)

options.text: Has done so unintentionally
Is within 4m of the halfway line
Is not interfering with play or an opponent
Is not gaining an advantage

question: A player crosses the halfway line in the act of carrying the ball and leaves less than 3 teammates in the opposition half. Where is the free kick taken?

options.text: On the offending team's 20m line
At the point where the player crossed the halfway line, to the opposition
On the 45m line
At the centre of the halfway line

question: If the defending team withdraws too many players and fails to keep 3 in the opposition half, where is the free kick awarded?

options.text: At the point where the breach occurred
On the offending team's 20m line
On the halfway line
On the opposition's 45m line

question: If the attacking team pushes too many players forward and fails to keep 4 in their own half, where is the free kick awarded?

options.text: On the offending team's 20m line
At the point where the player crossed the halfway line
On the halfway line
On the opposition's 13m line

question: When a team is awarded a free for a 4/3 structure breach, what option do they have?

options.text: They must take the free from the awarded position only
They may bring the ball out to the 40m arc to attempt a two-point score
They may choose a penalty kick instead
They may substitute a player without it counting

question: A team has a player ordered off (or sin-binned). Must they still comply with the 4/3 structure?

options.text: No, the structure requirement is waived when a player is off
Yes, they must maintain the 4 vs 3 structure
Only if the player was red-carded
Only in the first half

question: Under Core Enhancement 2A (Kick-Outs), when may the kick-out be taken?

options.text: Only after all players are outside the 20m line
The kick-out may be taken before all players are outside the 20m line; players may remain inside
Only after all players are outside the 40m arc
Only when the goalkeeper is in the small rectangle

question: If a player infringes the goalkeeper or another opposition player who is taking the kick-out, what is the penalty?

options.text: Free kick to the infringed team on their 20m line
Free kick awarded at the halfway line
Kick-out retaken
Yellow card and free on 13m line

question: If the goalkeeper is not taking the kick-out, where must the goalkeeper stay?

options.text: Outside the 20m line
In the small rectangle
On the goal line
Outside the 40m arc

question: Before another player on the attacking team may play the ball from a kick-out, the ball must:

options.text: Cross the 20m line only
Travel beyond the 20m line and outside the 40m arc
Be at least 13m from the goal
Touch the ground outside the small rectangle

question: At a kick-out, players may remain inside the 40m arc but must not be closer than how many metres from the ball?

options.text: 4m

question: A player in direct receipt of a kick-out may not pass the ball to their team's goalkeeper or to the player who took the kick-out:

options.text: Unless they are outside the 40m arc
Without another player playing the ball first
Unless the referee permits it
Under any circumstances

question: Under Core Enhancement 3A, inside the halfway line the goalkeeper can only receive the ball from a teammate when:

options.text: The ball is played from outside the 45m line
The teammate passing the ball is within the large rectangle
The goalkeeper is outside the small rectangle
The pass is a hand pass

question: If the goalkeeper receives a pass from a teammate inside the large rectangle, may they advance the ball outside the large rectangle?

options.text: No, they must kick it out
Yes, without restriction (subject to the goalkeeping rule on receiving passes beyond the midfield line)
Only after an opponent has touched the ball
Only within 5 seconds

question: If the goalkeeper intercepts the ball from an opposing player anywhere on the pitch, may they advance the ball?

options.text: No, they must release it within the large rectangle
Yes, without restriction (subject to the goalkeeping rule on receiving passes beyond the midfield line)
Only if they are inside their own 45m line
Only after throwing the ball

question: When a player shows dissent with the referee's decision to award a free to the opposing team, from where is the free kick taken?

options.text: From the original position only
50 metres more advantageous than the original position, up to the opponents' 13m line
From the halfway line
From the 45m line

question: When the 50m dissent advantage is applied, may the player taking the free choose to take it from outside the 40m arc even if the 50m advantage would place it inside the arc?

options.text: No, the kick must be from the 50m advantage position
Yes, the player has the option to take the free from outside the 40m arc
Only with the referee's permission
Only in extra time

question: At Under 18 or younger grades, an offender ordered off for ten minutes to the Sin Bin is shown which card?

options.text: Yellow Card
Red Card
Black Card
No card is shown

question: At Under 18 or younger grades, when a player is ordered off to the Sin Bin for ten minutes, may they be replaced?

options.text: No, the team plays with 14 for ten minutes
Yes, they may be replaced immediately by a Temporary Substitute for the duration
Only after five minutes
Yes, but it counts as one of the team's substitutions

question: What is the primary principle for a referee's positioning regarding the ball during open and set plays?

options.text: Stay level with the ball at all times
Try to be ahead of the ball as much as possible
Remain close to the halfway line
Follow the ball from behind

question: When is it a particularly good time for the referee to be constantly ahead of the ball?

options.text: During kick-outs only
When the ball is being played from side to side
Only in the last five minutes
When a team is attacking quickly

question: Kick-out: Can the goalkeeper take a kick-out immediately after a score or wide?

options.text: Yes. You do not have to wait for players to be outside the 20m line or the referee's consent
No. All players must be outside the 20m line first
No. The referee must give consent before the kick-out
Only after a score, not after a wide

question: Kick-out: Are there any restrictions for players on either team staying inside the 40m arc?

options.text: No. You just need to be 13m from the ball
Yes. All players must be outside the 40m arc before the kick-out
Yes. Only the attacking team may have players inside the 40m arc
Yes. Players must be at least 20m from the ball

question: Kick-out: What happens if you interfere with the goalkeeper or the player taking the kick-out?

options.text: It's a 50m penalty; the ball will be brought up to the halfway line
The kick-out is retaken
A free kick to the opposing team on the 20m line
A yellow card and free from the 13m line

question: Kick-out: I'm on the team taking the kick-out and I catch the ball inside the 40m arc. Can I play on?

options.text: No. It's a free kick against you from the position you received the ball
Yes. You may play on as normal
Yes, but only if you hand-pass first
The kick-out is retaken

question: Kick-out: Can you intercept an opposition kick-out inside the 40m arc?

options.text: Yes. Play on, provided you were 13m from the ball when it was kicked
No. It's a free kick against you from where you caught it
No. The ball must go outside the 40m arc before any player can play it
Yes, but only if you were outside the 20m line when it was kicked

question: Solo & Go: If you tap your foot off the ball, is that considered a solo & go?

options.text: No. It must be a 'toe-tap' – the ball must be released from the hand(s) to the foot and kicked back into the hand(s)
Yes. Any contact between foot and ball counts as a solo
Yes, provided the ball touches the ground first
Only if you use the same foot twice

question: Solo & Go: Can any player take a solo & go?

options.text: Yes
No. Only outfield players
No. Only the player in possession when the ball is put in play
Only after a kick-out or free kick

question: Solo & Go: Can you take a solo & go anywhere on the pitch?

options.text: There is one exception – you cannot take it inside the opposition 20m line
Yes. Anywhere on the pitch with no exceptions
No. Only between the 45m lines
No. You cannot take it inside either 20m line

question: Solo & Go: If you're fouled, can you give the ball to another player on your team so they can take a solo & go?

options.text: Yes. But don't delay – a solo & go must be taken immediately when you were awarded a free kick
No. Only the fouled player may take the solo & go
Yes, and there is no time limit
No. The ball must be kicked from the free kick position first

question: Solo & Go: If you're fouled, do you need to take the solo & go from the position where the foul occurred?

options.text: No. You can take a solo & go up to 4m from the position where the foul occurred
Yes. You must take it from the exact position of the foul
No. You may take it from anywhere on the pitch
Yes, unless the referee moves the ball for the 50m dissent rule

question: Solo & Go: Can you take a solo & go in any direction?

options.text: No. The solo & go must only be taken in a forwards or sideways direction
Yes. Any direction is allowed
No. Only in a forwards direction
Yes, but not towards your own goal

question: Solo & Go: What happens if you take a solo & go backwards?

options.text: A free kick is awarded to the opposition where the foul occurs
Play continues; the referee may give an advantage
The ball is given to the opposition for a throw-in
A free kick to the opposition on the halfway line

question: Solo & Go: What happens if you take a solo & go beyond 4m from where the foul occurred?

options.text: The referee will cancel the solo & go and ask the player to take the free kick from the position of the foul, from either the hands or from the ground
A free kick is awarded to the opposition
Play continues from where the ball ended up
The referee will award a hop ball

question: Solo & Go: What happens if you delay taking a solo & go?

options.text: If the solo & go is not taken 'immediately' the referee will cancel the solo & go and the free kick will have to be taken from the position of the foul, from either the hands or from the ground
A free kick is awarded to the opposition
The referee will give a verbal warning only
Play continues; no sanction

question: Solo & Go: What does 'immediately' mean?

options.text: After a foul, the solo & go must be taken at once and without delay
Within 5 seconds of the referee's whistle
Before the opposition can set up their defence
On the referee's signal only

question: Solo & Go: Can you take a solo & go after the ball is moved up 50m?

options.text: No. A solo & go can only be taken 4m from the position where the foul occurred
Yes. You may take a solo & go from the 50m advantage position
Yes, but only from the hands
Only if the referee permits it

question: Goalkeeper receiving a pass: What happens if the goalkeeper steps outside the large rectangle to receive a pass from a teammate?

options.text: A free kick is awarded from where the pass was made
A free kick to the opposition on the 20m line
Play continues; no sanction
A free kick from where the goalkeeper received the ball

question: Goalkeeper receiving a pass: Can you be in the large rectangle, receive a pass from a teammate who is outside the large rectangle, and then pass it to the goalkeeper?

options.text: No. If you are inside the large rectangle you can only pass to the goalkeeper if the ball has been played by an opposing player – e.g. you catch or intercept an opposition shot, kick or fist pass, before passing to your goalkeeper
Yes. You may receive from a teammate outside and then pass to the goalkeeper
Yes, provided the goalkeeper is inside the small rectangle
No. The goalkeeper can never receive a pass from a teammate inside the large rectangle

question: Goalkeeper receiving a pass: What happens if the goalkeeper intercepts an opposition pass outside the large rectangle?

options.text: They can play on as normal, but cannot receive a return pass from a teammate until they are inside the opposition half
A free kick is awarded to the opposition
They must release the ball immediately; they cannot advance with it
They can play on with no restrictions

question: Goalkeeper receiving a pass: Can the goalkeeper, while in possession, cross back into their own half after receiving a pass from a teammate in the opposition half?

options.text: Yes
No. Once in the opposition half they cannot return with the ball
Only if they release the ball before crossing the halfway line
Only after an opposition player has touched the ball

question: Goalkeeper receiving a pass: Your full-back blocks a shot outside the 13m line but the momentum of the ball carries it inside the large rectangle. Can the goalkeeper play that ball?

options.text: Yes. That would not be deemed as 'receiving the ball' from a teammate
No. A free kick is awarded from where the block occurred
No. The goalkeeper cannot play a ball that has been touched by a teammate inside the large rectangle
Only if the ball has crossed the 13m line first

question: Goalkeeper receiving a pass: A high ball is kicked into your full-back line and the ball breaks off the hand of one of your players and drops into the large rectangle. Can the goalkeeper play that ball?

options.text: Yes. A breaking ball that drops into the large rectangle would not be deemed as 'receiving the ball' from a teammate
No. A free kick is awarded to the opposition
No. Once a teammate has touched the ball it cannot be played by the goalkeeper in the large rectangle
Only if the touch was unintentional

question: Goalkeeper receiving a pass: Can the goalkeeper position themselves anywhere on the field, including for opposition kick-outs?

options.text: Yes. The goalkeeper can position themselves anywhere on the field of play
No. They must stay inside the large rectangle for opposition kick-outs
Only in their own half
No. They must stay inside the small rectangle until the ball is in play

question: Goalkeeper receiving a pass: What happens if your goalkeeper, who is on your half-back line, receives a pass from a teammate?

options.text: If the goalkeeper catches a pass from a teammate inside their half of the field, a free kick is awarded to the opposition from where the pass is made
Play continues; the half-back line is treated as neutral
A free kick to the opposition on the 20m line
A free kick from where the goalkeeper received the ball

question: Goalkeeper receiving a pass: You're the goalkeeper, outside the large rectangle. Your centre half-back attempts a pass to your corner back but the pass goes over the corner back's head. You leave the large rectangle, go to the ball and start to play it on the ground. Is that allowed because the pass wasn't for you and you didn't pick the ball up?

options.text: No. Even though you did not receive a direct pass from a teammate you did receive the ball from a teammate. Since you're outside your large rectangle and in your own half, the opposition get a free kick from where your teammate made the attempted pass
Yes. Playing the ball on the ground is allowed
Yes. Because the pass wasn't intended for you it's not a breach
Yes. Because you didn't pick the ball up it's allowed

question: 4/3 Structure Rule: Can the goalkeeper be one of the three players you keep in your half of the field?

options.text: No. You need to keep 3 outfield players in each half of the pitch
Yes. The goalkeeper may count as one of the three
Yes, but only when taking a kick-out
Only in the opposition half

question: 4/3 Structure Rule: Is a goalkeeper an outfield player when they are playing outfield?

options.text: No. An 'outfield player' is defined as any other player other than the goalkeeper
Yes. When the goalkeeper leaves the goal area they count as an outfield player
Yes, when they are in the opposition half
Only for the 4/3 structure count

question: 4/3 Structure Rule: Can you put a forward in the goalkeeper's jersey and give his outfield jersey to the goalkeeper, so the goalkeeper wears an outfield jersey but plays in goals and could receive a pass inside the large rectangle in your half?

options.text: It is a team's decision to allocate jerseys, but you must still keep 3 outfield players in the opposition half when defending. The player in goals must comply with goalkeeper rules (e.g. for kick-outs, stay in small rectangle if not taking it; only the goalkeeper may play the ball on the ground inside the small rectangle)
Yes. Swapping jerseys means the person in the outfield jersey can receive passes in the large rectangle
No. Jerseys must match the player's designated position
No. Only the designated goalkeeper may wear the goalkeeper's jersey

question: 4/3 Structure Rule: If your teammate or several teammates are black or red carded, how will that affect the 4/3 structure?

options.text: If a player is ordered off, the team may adjust the number required inside the midfield line so they always have a maximum 11 attacking or maximum 11 defending (excluding the goalkeeper). The team will not be disadvantaged by the 4/3 rule when a player is ordered off
The 4/3 structure no longer applies; the team with fewer players is exempt
The team must still keep exactly 4 in their half and 3 in the opposition half regardless
A free kick is awarded to the opposition each time the structure is broken

question: Scoring: If your foot is on the 40m arc and you score, is that allowed?

options.text: Yes. If it goes directly over the bar
No. Your whole body must be outside the 40m arc
No. The ball must be struck from outside the arc
Only for a point, not a goal

question: Scoring: You take a kick from outside the arc; it lands in the large rectangle and your full-forward punches it over the crossbar. Is it counted as 1 or 2 points?

options.text: 1 point. A shot for 2 points must go directly over the bar; it only counts as 1 point if it is flicked, palmed or punched over the crossbar by a player on either team
2 points. A point from outside the arc is always 2 points
2 points. Because the initial kick was from outside the arc
No score. The ball was played in the large rectangle before going over

question: Scoring: During an attack one of your players was fouled inside the 40m arc. Do you have the option of taking the free kick outside the 40m arc and attempting a two-point shot?

options.text: No. The free kick must be taken from the position where the original foul was committed, and this spot should be marked
Yes. You may bring the ball out to the 40m arc for a two-point attempt
Yes, but only if the referee agrees
Only for a free awarded for a 4/3 structure breach

question: Scoring: You took a free kick out of your hands and went past the spot marked by the referee with vanishing foam. Is that okay?

options.text: No. The referee will cancel your free kick and throw in the ball where the foul occurred
Yes. You may advance up to 4m from the mark
Yes. The mark is only a guide
Only if you were taking a solo & go

question: Advanced Mark: After an Advanced Mark is taken by the attacking team and the player decides to play on by immediately passing backwards to an on-coming attacking player, will the referee deem that advantage to be over?

options.text: No. The play may continue (no matter which direction the player moves or passes the ball) for as long as the referee deems that there is the potential of an advantage to the attacking team
Yes. A backwards pass ends the advantage
Yes. Once the mark is taken, playing on ends the advantage
Only if the ball goes outside the 45m line

question: Advanced Mark: You play in the full-back line. If an opposition player catches an advanced mark, can you tackle them immediately, or do you have to wait until they take four steps?

options.text: Yes. You can immediately tackle the player who catches an advanced mark
No. You must wait until they take four steps
You must wait until they signal to take the kick
You may only tackle once they have played the ball

question: Advanced Mark: You caught an Advanced Mark just inside the 20m line, cut inside to go for a goal and an opposition defender wrapped their hands around you. The referee blew for the foul. Do you get a free from where the foul occurred?

options.text: In this scenario you are likely to be awarded a penalty. Rule 5.41 applies when a player is denied a goal-scoring opportunity because an opponent deliberately pulled them down (including being held up), deliberately tripped them, or deliberately collided with them. The offending player will also receive a Black Card
Yes. A free from where the foul occurred
A free from the 13m line
A free from the 20m line only

question: Advanced Mark: An opposition player makes an Advanced Mark and takes a shot at goal that your keeper saves. Can you play on?

options.text: No. The referee will deem that no advantage has accrued to the team of the player awarded the Mark, will indicate 'no advantage gained' and take the ball back to the point of the Mark
Yes. Your team may play on from the save
Yes. Your keeper may kick out from the save
Only if the shot was outside the 20m line

question: Advanced Mark: An opposition player makes an Advanced Mark and takes a shot that goes wide. What happens?

options.text: The referee will deem that no advantage has accrued to the team of the player awarded the Mark, will indicate 'no advantage gained' and take the ball back to the point of the Mark
Your team gets a kick-out from the end line
Your team may play on from the wide ball
A throw-in to your team from where the ball went out

question: Advanced Mark: An opposition player makes an Advanced Mark and passes to a teammate, and you intercept. Can you play on?

options.text: No. The referee will deem that no advantage has accrued to the team of the player awarded the Mark, will indicate 'no advantage gained' and take the ball back to the point of the Mark
Yes. Your team may play on from the interception
Yes. An interception always allows play to continue
Only if the pass was outside the 45m line

question: Advanced Mark: You make an Advanced Mark and take the defender on. As you do this you take 6 steps and the referee blows for your foul. What happens next?

options.text: Since you committed a 'technical foul' before you had accrued an advantage, the referee will stop play and allow you to take the Mark from its original position
A free kick to the opposition from where you took the 6th step
A free kick to the opposition from the point of the Mark
The referee will throw in the ball where the foul occurred

question: Advanced Mark: You make an Advanced Mark and take the defender on. As you do this you charge at the defender and knock them over. The referee blows for your foul. Can you go back and take a kick from the original position of the Mark?

options.text: No. You committed an 'aggressive foul' so the referee will award a free kick to the opposition and apply any relevant disciplinary action
Yes. You may take the Mark from its original position
Yes, but you will receive a yellow card
The referee will throw in the ball where the foul occurred

question: Advanced Mark: If you make an Advanced Mark, can you play the ball backwards outside the 40m to create an opportunity for a 2pt shot?

options.text: In theory yes. In practice, unlikely that a referee will allow the advantage to continue in that scenario
Yes. The referee must allow any direction of play
No. You cannot play the ball backwards from an Advanced Mark
No. A 2pt shot cannot be created from a backwards pass

question: Advanced Mark: Your midfielder catches a Kick Out Mark outside your 45m line, then kicks it to inside the opposition 20m line and you catch it. Can that be considered an Advanced Mark?

options.text: Yes. The rules were amended to allow this scenario from a Kick Out Mark. Note: an Advanced Mark cannot be taken from a free kick or sideline kick
No. An Advanced Mark can only be from a kick from outside the 45m line by the same team in open play
No. A catch from a Kick Out Mark cannot lead to an Advanced Mark
Only if the kick was from the hands

question: Deliberately holding up a player: You have the ball and are taking on the defender. They wrap their arms around you so you cannot move forward. Will you still get a free?

options.text: Yes. You get a free kick. In addition, the referee will deem this 'Cynical Play for holding up a player' and the defender will receive a Black Card
No. Only a verbal warning to the defender
Yes, a free kick only; no card
A free kick and a yellow card to the defender

question: Delaying the play: You're fouled on your 65m line and about to take a quick free kick when an opposition player blocks you. The referee brings the ball up 50m, which is inside the 40m arc. Can you bring the ball back to the arc and take a free kick for 2pts?

options.text: Yes. If you are delayed the referee advances the ball 50m (up to opponents' 13m line). If the foul was outside the arc and the advancement brought it inside the arc, you have the option of taking the free from outside the 40m arc for 2pts
No. You must take the free from the 50m advancement position
No. The 2pt option only applies to 4/3 structure frees
Only if the referee permits it

question: Handing the ball back: If you over-carry the ball and the referee calls a foul, can you just drop the ball and get yourself into a defensive position?

options.text: No. If you don't 'hand over' the ball by giving it directly to the nearest opposition player in a prompt and respectful manner, the referee will consider that you are purposefully delaying play and will advance the ball 50m
Yes. Dropping the ball is sufficient
Yes, as long as you don't throw it
Only if you drop it at the referee's feet

question: Handing the ball back: Your teammate fouled the ball and then kick-passed it to you, and you're 30m from where the foul occurred. What are you supposed to do?

options.text: You need to look for the nearest opposition player and hand them the ball. If you don't, the referee will consider that you are purposely delaying play and will advance the ball 50m
Drop the ball where you are and let the referee place it
Bring the ball back to where the foul occurred
Give the ball to the referee

question: Dissent: You are not the team captain or the nominated deputy, but you don't know why the referee gave a free against you. Surely you can ask them why they made that decision?

options.text: If you do, you will concede a free kick and the ball will be advanced 50m. Only the team captain or a nominated deputy may speak to the referee to seek clarification of a decision, and only during a break in play
Yes. Any player may ask the referee for clarification at any time
Yes, but only after the free kick has been taken
You may ask at the next break in play

question: Dissent: Your manager gave the referee and linesman abuse after a free was awarded against your team. The referee advanced the ball to your 13m line. The opposition player then moved the ball back to the top of the arc and scored a 2-pointer to win. Is that allowed?

options.text: Yes. If a team official displays misconduct towards Match Officials, the referee awards a free on the offending team's 13m line at centre of the scoring space or, at the free taker's option, a free from the apex of the 40m arc. If that option is taken, two points are awarded for a score over the crossbar between the posts
No. The free must be taken from the 13m line only
No. A score from the arc option can only be 1 point
The referee should have sent the manager to the stand only

question: Moving the ball up: If the referee is moving the ball up 50m, do you need to wait until they bring the ball up to take the free kick?

options.text: Yes. If the referee is advancing the ball 50m, you need to wait until they re-position the ball. However, you may instead take a solo & go or a free kick from the place where the foul occurred
No. You may take the free as soon as the referee signals
No. You may take from either the original position or the 50m position immediately
Only if you want to take from the 50m position

question: Contributing to a melee: If you go to get your teammate out of a melee, is that okay?

options.text: Yes, so long as you are solely engaged with trying to remove your teammate who is involved in the melee
No. Entering a melee in any circumstances is an offence
Only if the referee has not yet blown the whistle
Yes, but you may receive a yellow card

question: Contributing to a melee: Your teammate is being pushed around in a melee. Can you go in and try to get the opposition player to stop?

options.text: No. If you are the 3rd or subsequent player into a melee and you are not solely engaged in trying to remove your teammate, the referee will send you to the Sin Bin
Yes. Trying to stop an opposition player from pushing your teammate is allowed
Yes, as long as you don't make contact
Only the team captain may intervene

question: Stop clock: Can you play on if the referee blows the whistle for the end of the half or game, or if the hooter blows?

options.text: No. The game immediately ends
Yes. Play continues until the ball goes out of play
Yes, if you are in a goalscoring position
Only after the referee's whistle, not the hooter

question: Stop clock: You're just about to take a shot and the hooter goes. If you scored a point, would it count?

options.text: No. The game ends immediately
Yes. A shot already in motion when the hooter sounds counts if it goes over the bar
Yes, if the ball has left your foot before the hooter
The referee may allow it at their discretion

question: Stop clock: Your team takes a shot and the ball leaves the boot or fist just before the hooter sounds, and it results in a score. Does the score count?

options.text: Yes. If the ball is in the air after the hooter sounds, a score may be awarded. The ball must go directly over the bar or in the net – it cannot be flicked on by a teammate or opposition player
No. The game ends immediately when the hooter sounds
Only for a point, not a goal
Only if the referee had not yet blown the whistle

question: Stop clock: Your team has been awarded a free kick and the hooter goes. Can you take the free kick?

options.text: Yes. For the score to count, the ball must go directly over the bar – it cannot be flicked on by a teammate or opposition player
No. The game ends when the hooter sounds; the free kick is not taken
Only if the free was inside the 45m line
The referee decides whether to allow it

question: Stop clock: You have a penalty and the hooter sounds. The penalty is taken, the goalkeeper palms the ball but it still hits the net. Does the goal count even though the keeper touched the ball?

options.text: Yes. If a penalty was awarded but not taken before the hooter sounded, the penalty can be taken and if it results in a score (including only the goalkeeper touching the ball), that score shall be awarded
No. Once the goalkeeper touches the ball the goal cannot stand
No. The game had ended when the hooter sounded
The penalty must be retaken if the keeper touched it
